item.title:
RT by @0xTaker: I‚Äôve been thinking about this tweet a lot.
There‚Äôs been a wave of newcomers that voice disconcern > get angry when their feedback isn‚Äôt reciprocated > become resentful and this cycle persists.
But if you aren‚Äôt getting a response on Twitter here are some more impactful ways to voice feedback: - Writing a proposal in https://ethresear.ch/ about your idea - Building out a community to support your idea or empower other builders - Build out the idea itself (with tooling or infra)
There‚Äôs a lot of pointing fingers as to who is going to change Ethereum and it‚Äôs you, it‚Äôs me, it‚Äôs every builder that is working in this ecosystem. If you see a gap in the system the EF is there to empower you with grants or mentorship but you are have to create actionable change.
But that sounds hard. It‚Äôs not and I promise you can do it if you really want to. Now, let‚Äôs walk through my favourite examples of people that did this.
item.dc:creator: @html_tina
item.description:
I‚Äôve been thinking about this tweet a lot.

There‚Äôs been a wave of newcomers that voice disconcern > get angry when their feedback isn‚Äôt reciprocated > become resentful and this cycle persists.

But if you aren‚Äôt getting a response on Twitter here are some more impactful ways to voice feedback:
- Writing a proposal in ethresear.ch/ about your idea
- Building out a community to support your idea or empower other builders
- Build out the idea itself (with tooling or infra)

There‚Äôs a lot of pointing fingers as to who is going to change Ethereum and it‚Äôs you, it‚Äôs me, it‚Äôs every builder that is working in this ecosystem. If you see a gap in the system the EF is there to empower you with grants or mentorship but you are have to create actionable change.

But that sounds hard. It‚Äôs not and I promise you can do it if you really want to. Now, let‚Äôs walk through my favourite examples of people that did this.

nitter.freedit.eu/ameensol/status/1867917439645937839#m

item.title: RT by @0xTaker: We looked into the option of selling multiple TimeBoost licenses. While having multiple arbitrageurs with time advantage has obvious advantages and disadvantages, there is a considerable probability one monopolist will buy all of them, given extra value from owning all licenses is sufficiently large: http://research.arbitrum.io/t/auctioning-multiple-timeboost-licenses/9699. This is a joint effort with @EdFelten. We thank @BenBerg07141321 for his feedback.
item.dc:creator: @kakia1989
item.description: We looked into the option of selling multiple TimeBoost licenses. While having multiple arbitrageurs with time advantage has obvious advantages and disadvantages, there is a considerable probability one monopolist will buy all of them, given extra value from owning all licenses is sufficiently large: research.arbitrum.io/t/aucti‚Ä¶. This is a joint effort with @EdFelten. We thank @BenBerg07141321 for his feedback.

item.title:
RT by @0xTaker: DoubleZero = a faster internet
Those of you in the old school who believe DoubleZero is a bubble simply have not understood the new mathematics of high-performance global base-level internet connectivity, or you did not care enough to try. Jitter is mathematically impossible in this new paradigm, as are dropped transactions and everything else
Lucky for you we @heliuslabs summarized everything you need to educate yourself about DoubleZero
item.dc:creator: @__lostin__
item.description:
DoubleZero = a faster internet

Those of you in the old school who believe DoubleZero is a bubble simply have not understood the new mathematics of high-performance global base-level internet connectivity, or you did not care enough to try. Jitter is mathematically impossible in this new paradigm, as are dropped transactions and everything else

Lucky for you we @heliuslabs summarized everything you need to educate yourself about DoubleZero

item.title: RT by @0xTaker: My EC talk on Tullock contests in crypto/web3 is now on YT. (Link in replies.) Covers mining, staking, execution tickets, shared sequencing. Includes ongoing work with @PGarimidi @mikeneuder. Thx to @tarunchitra @theo_diamandis @ks_kulk @malleshpai @MaxResnick1 for the invite!

item.description: My EC talk on Tullock contests in crypto/web3 is now on YT. (Link in replies.) Covers mining, staking, execution tickets, shared sequencing. Includes ongoing work with @PGarimidi @mikeneuder. Thx to @tarunchitra @theo_diamandis @ks_kulk @malleshpai @MaxResnick1 for the invite!

item.title:
RT by @0xTaker: Who owns the write lock?
This is the critical question when discussing MEV and broader blockchain designs.
Lets walk through different rollup centric designs and evaluate the rights of different actors in the system: proposers, relays, sequencers, gateways, and inclusion lists
item.dc:creator: @Jskybowen
item.description:
Who owns the write lock?

This is the critical question when discussing MEV and broader blockchain designs.

Lets walk through different rollup centric designs and evaluate the rights of different actors in the system: proposers, relays, sequencers, gateways, and inclusion lists

item.title:
RT by @0xTaker: SQLite is already fast. But can we make it even faster?
Today I will share my notes on "Serverless Runtime / Database Co-Design With Asynchronous I/O" paper by @penberg and authors who propose an Async I/O design for SQLite.
The result: Up to 100x reduction in tail latency!
This is the foundational paper behind Limbo, the SQLite rewrite in Rust. Let's dive in.
item.dc:creator: @iavins
item.description:
SQLite is already fast. But can we make it even faster?

Today I will share my notes on "Serverless Runtime / Database Co-Design With Asynchronous I/O" paper by @penberg and authors who propose an Async I/O design for SQLite.

The result: Up to 100x reduction in tail latency!

This is the foundational paper behind Limbo, the SQLite rewrite in Rust. Let's dive in.
